body: A tour bus carrying 30 Chinatown residents home after a long night in Atlantic City careered out of control here this morning and slammed into a tree, injuring everyone aboard, two critically. The accident came three days after eight people were killed when their bus to Atlantic City spun off the road just five miles from the site of today's crash.
title: 2d Bus on Atlantic City Run Crashes, Injuring All Aboard

body: When Staten Island got its one-way toll on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in 1986, residents of lower Manhattan were not the only ones who cried foul. In Brooklyn, too, the plan met with strong, and continuing, opposition. But there is an even bigger traffic issue in Brooklyn today: the impending reconstruction of many sections of Interstate 278.
title: Gowanus Expressway: Trouble Overhead

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani seemed to be inaugurating a new era of large-scale public works two years ago when he called for the construction of a rail tunnel under the Hudson River to carry freight between the Brooklyn waterfront and the rest of the country. The idea drew headlines, and Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato quickly
geo_facet: PORT OF NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY
title: Study Questions Plan for Hudson Rail Tunnel

body: The signs of rebirth had been unmistakable in the Brooklyn waterfront neighborhood of Red Hook, a place long known best for its car impound lots, its eyesore of industrial blocks and one of the largest public housing projects in the country. Lately, there had been new shops, an uptick in real estate prices and an influx of artists and young
title: Angry Reception Greets Trash Plan in Brooklyn

body: IN New York, many regular people -- meaning those who do not make hundreds of thousands of dollars a year -- do not think of landlords as being like them. title: Habitats / Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn; An Apartment Seeker Becomes a Landlord

body: Two arts organizations are in conflict in Brownstone Brooklyn. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; What's in a Name? A Lawsuit

body: THE sun was setting like a fat tomato behind the Statue of Liberty just as Armando Babillo hooked a 20-inch sea bass, flashing silver in the light, from the end of the new $3 million Louis Valentino Jr. Pier at the end of Coffey Street. ''Vivo en el proyecto de Red Hook,'' Mr. Babillo said, adding proudly, ''We will have this for Sunday dinner.''
title: Up From the Ruins, Red Hook Faces a Dump

body: Dance Theater Workshop and the Danspace Project of St. Mark's Church presented the 14th Annual Dance and Performance Awards on Friday night at the Joyce Theater. The awards, chosen by a panel of judges, are familiarly known as the Bessies, and are named after Bessie Schonberg, a noted teacher of dance composition. They honor achievements in dance
title: Jollity and Some Serious Moments at the Bessie Awards

body: The Tunnel Garage Q: A developer is proposing the demolition of the old Tunnel Garage, at Broome and Thompson Streets, a project we are opposing. Who designed this building? . . . title: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; House on Fifth, Tunnel Garage, a Brooklyn Office

body: THE thick, green water of the Gowanus Canal was baking in the hot August sun. Hollow windows of empty buildings and twisted fences brooded down on the water. Almost nothing stirred in the heat, except a plump black rat scurrying across broken stones that lay on the shore. The only other sign of life was David Lefkowitz's 21-foot powerboat, which
title: The Gowanus Canal: An Appreciation

body: The deadly looking water gun that fooled police officers and led them to shoot and critically injure a 16-year-old boy in Brooklyn on Sunday night was another reminder of what critics said yesterday has been an all-too-common problem: realistic toy guns that, although they are banned by law, are still too easy for children to get. The water gun
title: After Shooting by Police, Critics Say Illegal Toy Guns Are Still Too Easy to Get

body: In a sign that developers are increasingly forced to scout out unlikely locales for new projects, a Manhattan company said yesterday that it would build a huge entertainment complex along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn that would include the city's largest multiplex movie theater. The project, to be known as Brooklyn Commons, would be part of a
title: Theater Complex Planned for Brooklyn

body: The muck-ridden Gowanus Canal, which dates to the 19th century and runs through Cobble Hill, Park Slope and Carroll Gardens, has been so smelly that for decades it's been compared to the River Styx, the mythological river of the dead. Many people who live nearby have all but given up hope of seeing something done about the odor. But now the city is
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS; Dredging Up A Revived Waterway

body: Mimi Goese lives in one of those old New York City apartments whose rooms are so tiny that they feel like a complex of cages. Yet Ms. Goese, a 38-year-old performing artist, has transformed this standard walk-up into enchanted chambers. A vast window she cut into the wall between the kitchen and the living room opens up an unexpected vista. A
title: Carving a Path Of Innovations; Live and Electronic Music Blend in a Varied Career

body: Most people looking at the charred remains of the Bona Fide Fuel Oil Company in a gray, industrial section of Gowanus, Brooklyn, see hills of bricks, rusted scrap metal and a bunch of old tires. But preservationists see a site that may merit historic landmark status some day. They believe that the remains of 256 soldiers of the Maryland Brigade,
title: Brooklyn Fire May Lead to Revolutionary Graves

body: FOR CHILDREN Theater ''CITY, CITY'' -- Central Park will provide the setting for the National Dance Institute's event of the year, a musical involving 1,700 schoolchildren, ages 9 to 15, who will celebrate the many faces of New York City in dance. body: When the dust settled this week after the House passed its mammoth $217 billion, six-year highway bill, most New York lawmakers walked away ecstatic about the millions they managed to reap for their state. The bill has 47 percent more for New York State than did the last highway bill, passed in 1991, including $652.2 million from a $9 billion
title: State Makes A Heavy Haul In House Bill For Transport

body: Reliving a beating that exposed longstanding tensions between two Brooklyn neighborhoods, a black man from Red Hook testified yesterday how he was chased through traffic by vengeful white youths from Carroll Gardens who beat him while shouting racial slurs. The attack took place on Sept. 20, 1997, on busy Hamilton Avenue, which for decades has
title: 1997 Brooklyn Attack Recounted in Court

body: THERE are two commonly held beliefs about today's New York. No. 1: Things are good. No. 2: Everyone agrees about No. 1. The prevailing wisdom holds that the city is basking in a glorious period of renewal, evidenced and enhanced by a robust economy, a revitalized cultural scene and surging self-confidence. After all, the argument goes, Wall Street
title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

body: For more than 35 years, as Cobble Hill, Park Slope, and other Brooklyn neighborhoods of brownstone and old brick have revived, a mile-long corridor through the middle of the area has continued to crumble, collect weeds and drive people away. The dead zone extends for several blocks along the banks of the malodorous Gowanus Canal, a dead-end
title: Flushing Out the Foul And the Frustration; A New Vista for a Dead-End Canal

body: FOR CHILDREN Theater ''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD,'' a new updated musical version of the fairy tale, featuring a bubble-gum company executive, a podiatrist and a hip grandmother, presented by Theaterworks/USA.
